items.title: cannot load model python
items.body:
hello,
I want to load a downloaded german fasttext model as such:
`ft = fasttext.load_model('cc.de.300.bin')`
i downloaded it from h[ttps://fasttext.cc/docs/en/crawl-vectors.html ](url) 

when i run the cell it gives me a warning and an error:
`Warning : `load_model` does not return WordVectorModel or SupervisedModel any more, but a `FastText` object which is very similar.`

`ValueError: cc.de.300.bin cannot be opened for loading!`
Any help is greatly appreciated!

items.title: Why is recall nan, f1score > 1 when calculated with model.test_label ?
items.body:
I am training a binary classification model with autotune with `fasttext==0.9.2`, and get a nan value for the per-class recall and nonsensical values for the F1 score when calling `model.test_label`.

To reproduce, I came up with a reproducible example:

```python
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
import sklearn.datasets
import zipfile
import csv
import pprint
import wget
from fasttext import train_supervised
import fasttext.util

data = sklearn.datasets.fetch_20newsgroups(categories=['alt.atheism', 'sci.space'])
df = pd.DataFrame(data = np.c_[data['data'], data['target']]).rename({0:'text', 1:'class'}, axis = 'columns')

# assign labels
df["label"] = df["class"].apply(lambda row: '__label__Atheism' if row == "0" else "__label__Space")

# clean text features
df["text"] = df["text"].apply(lambda row: row.replace("\n", " ").replace("\r", " "))

# do train and validation splitting
train, test = train_test_split(df[["label", "text"]])

# dump train and validation
train.to_csv("train.csv", index = False, header=False, sep=" ", quoting=csv.QUOTE_NONE, escapechar=" ")
test.to_csv("dev.csv", index = False, header=False, sep=" ", quoting=csv.QUOTE_NONE, escapechar=" ")

print("downloading zipped word vectors...")
wget.download("https://dl.fbaipublicfiles.com/fasttext/vectors-english/wiki-news-300d-1M.vec.zip", 'wiki-news-300d-1M.vec.zip')

print("inflating word vectors...")
zip_ref = zipfile.ZipFile("wiki-news-300d-1M.vec.zip", 'r')
zip_ref.extractall(".")
zip_ref.close()

print("training model...")
model = train_supervised(
    input="train.csv",
    dim=300,
    verbose=2,
    pretrainedVectors="wiki-news-300d-1M.vec",
    autotuneValidationFile="dev.csv",
    autotuneDuration=300
)

# check model predictions
print(model.predict("What does God need with a starship?", k=1))

# do validation
validation_report = model.test_label("dev.csv")

print("validation summary:")
pprint.pprint(validation_report)
```

The code downloads a subset of a standard dataset (20news), reformats it into train and test sets, gets wiki-en word vectors and trains fasttext with autotune.

The output of the final bit of code, is
```
validation summary:
{'__label__Atheism': {'f1score': 1.8473282442748091,
                      'precision': 0.9236641221374046,
                      'recall': nan},
 '__label__Space': {'f1score': 1.8695652173913044,
                    'precision': 0.9347826086956522,
                    'recall': nan}}
```

Recall is somehow `nan` and the f1score exceeds 1 (it's twice the value of precision).

Seems to me (wild guess) that something funny is happening with my value of `gold` in 

https://github.com/facebookresearch/fastText/blob/b64e359d5485dda4b4b5074494155d18e25c8d13/src/meter.h#L39

and

https://github.com/facebookresearch/fastText/blob/b64e359d5485dda4b4b5074494155d18e25c8d13/src/meter.h#L45 which is zero while it shouldn't be.

I also found somebody else experiencing a similar problem on SO: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/61787119/fasttext-recall-is-nan-but-precision-is-a-number 

Am I doing something wrong (e.g. in the dataset preprocessing) or is this a bug?

What I am worried about is that problems in the computation of the F1 score may make autotune convergence troublesome.

`model.predict` on short chunks of text seems to be yielding sensible results.

items.title: Python method to get nearest neighbor vectors for a vector
items.body:
The method "get_nearest_neighbors" can only be applied to a word, not to a vector. However, for a calculated vector (e.g. an average vector) it would be good to get the N closest vectors to the given vector. 

Apparently this was possible with the now deprecated library pyfasttext but the new library seems to lack quite a number of useful methods. 

(and it does not seem to have a `fasttext.__version__` declared.)

items.title: Useless warning message on load_model
items.body:
In the Python bindings of version 0.9.2, every time I call `load_model` - which in my understanding is the correct way to load saved models - fastText prints this message on stderr:

> Warning : `load_model` does not return WordVectorModel or SupervisedModel any more, but a `FastText` object which is very similar.

It's defined on [this line](https://github.com/facebookresearch/fastText/blob/master/python/fasttext_module/fasttext/FastText.py#L440)

I understand that sometimes it's useful to explain API changes to users, especially when deprecated features are being accessed and better ways exist. But this seems a bit excessive, since there is no other way of loading the model so no easy way to avoid the message.

I silenced the warning by monkeypatching `eprint` like this:

    fasttext.FastText.eprint = lambda x: None

This is related to #909 which reported a problem (since fixed) that the warning message was printed as a blank line.

items.title: Fasttext word vectors: Why English word vectors yield better results?
items.body:
I have been working on a text classification task with texts in English, German and French. I trained the same neural network for each language using the pre-trained word vectors provided by Fasttext (so English, German and French word-vectors were used).
But the accuracy of the English model (for English texts) is always higher by at least 10 percent than the German and French models. 
How can this be explained? is it because the pre-trained word-vectors for English are somehow "better" or more "accurate" compared to word vectors in other languages? Or is it not necessarily related to fasttext models?

- More flexible appearance - Customizable layouts, CSS modules, etc
- Embeddable interactive React components within markdown via MDX

Also the Docusaraus team, has converted many of fb documents to v2 see facebook/docusaurus#1834. So I'll help you with this feature request, let me know what are your opinions.

```

        model = fasttext.train_unsupervised(d, dim = dimensions, epoch=n_epoch, minCount= min_count, thread= threads)
```

Here **data** is a python generator. in each iteration, **d** holds a single Bangla sentence as string type. After running the code, I am getting the following ValueError. 

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
```

Is there something I'm doing wrong?

This is my code if you need it.
```
import fasttext
from os import path
from data_preprocess import load_pickle_files, tokenize_sentence, tokenize_word
import time

class DataProcessor(object):

        self.filename = filename
 
    def __iter__(self):
        articles_generator = load_pickle_files(self.filename)
        
        for an_article in articles_generator:
            sentence_generator = tokenize_sentence(an_article)
            for sentence in sentence_generator:
                data=[]
                for word in tokenize_word(sentence):

def ft_train(dimensions, n_epoch, min_count=2, threads=4):

if __name__ == "__main__":
```

Docusaurus 2 brings about many improvements:

- More flexible appearance - Customizable layouts, CSS modules, etc
- Embeddable interactive React components within markdown via MDX

I will be your POC in helping you throughout the migration process. Let me know what you think!

cc @yangshun @endiliey

items.title: Missing SOVERSION in CMakeList.txt
items.body:
# Problem

If try to make rpm package for myself, I've noticed that rpmlint claims error such as:

```
fasttext-libs.x86_64: E: invalid-soname /usr/lib64/libfasttext.so libfasttext.so
The soname of the library is neither of the form lib<libname>.so.<major> or
lib<libname>-<major>.so.
```

Actually, so version is not used.

# Expected

It seems that it is good manner to respect SOVERSION and bump version if
API is changed.

```
/usr/lib64/libfasttext.so -> /usr/lib64/libfasttext.so.0
/usr/lib64/libfasttext.so.0
```
Above example indicates SOVERSION 0 case.

# Actual

There is no soversion. /usr/lib64/libfasttext.so is used.

items.title: Improving load_vectors function
items.body:
I have changed a bit the `load_vectors` function and it allows me reduce the RAM usage in approximately 75%. I would like to propose add this function instead of the original.
Below you can see a benchmark using [memory_profiler](https://pypi.org/project/memory-profiler/)

```
$ python -m memory_profiler vectors.py
Filename: vectors.py

Line #    Mem usage    Increment   Line Contents
================================================
     3   38.508 MiB   38.508 MiB   @profile
     4                             def load_vectors(fname):
     5   38.508 MiB    0.000 MiB       fin = io.open(fname, 'r', encoding='utf-8', newline='\n', errors='ignore')
     6   38.508 MiB    0.000 MiB       n, d = map(int, fin.readline().split())
     7   38.508 MiB    0.000 MiB       data = {}
     8 38164.562 MiB    0.262 MiB       for line in fin:
     9 38164.562 MiB   11.781 MiB           tokens = line.rstrip().split(' ')
    10 38164.562 MiB   48.215 MiB           data[tokens[0]] = map(float, tokens[1:])
    11 38164.562 MiB    0.000 MiB       return data

_________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

$ python -m memory_profiler np_vectors.py
Filename: np_vectors.py

Line #    Mem usage    Increment   Line Contents
================================================
     4   66.789 MiB   66.789 MiB   @profile
     5                             def load_vectors(fname):
     6   66.789 MiB    0.000 MiB       fin = io.open(fname, 'r', encoding='utf-8', newline='\n', errors='ignore')
     7   66.789 MiB    0.000 MiB       n, d = map(int, fin.readline().split())

    11 5401.383 MiB   48.008 MiB           data[tokens[0]] = np.array(list(map(float, tokens[1:])))
    12 5401.383 MiB    0.000 MiB       return data 
```

As you can see, the original function use 38164.562 MiB vs 5401.383 MiB of the modified function.
I also add the scripts

**vectors.py** (Original function)
```
import io

@profile
def load_vectors(fname):
    fin = io.open(fname, 'r', encoding='utf-8', newline='\n', errors='ignore')
    n, d = map(int, fin.readline().split())
    data = {}
    for line in fin:
        tokens = line.rstrip().split(' ')
        data[tokens[0]] = map(float, tokens[1:])
    return data

if __name__ == '__main__':
    load_vectors('cc.es.300.vec')
```

**np_vectors.py** (Modified function)
```
import io
import numpy as np

@profile
def load_vectors(fname):
    fin = io.open(fname, 'r', encoding='utf-8', newline='\n', errors='ignore')
    n, d = map(int, fin.readline().split())
    data = {}
    for line in fin:
        tokens = line.rstrip().split(' ')
        data[tokens[0]] = np.array(list(map(float, tokens[1:])))
    return data

if __name__ == '__main__':
    load_vectors('cc.es.300.vec')
```

items.title: Wrong Label tagging when train data has repeated words.

The day is good - Wish

This case, I trained a model with WordNgram 3 and loss function OVA. 

If "**good**" keyword comes under any non-relevant text. The model is wrongly tagging it with the label "Wish" . 
Ex., I went for walk a its good.
If I remove "**good**" from the above text, I got lesser probability around 1%  which is correct. 
When "**good**" is not removed, it predicted as 100% and tagged with Wish label.

How do I prevent this kind of issues?
Is there any way i can reduce the weight of certain words?

items.title: train_supervised with pretrainedVectors of 5GB size - 5 times slower than without pretrained?
items.body:
First apologies if I should not post this question as 'issue', in which case please kindly point me to any mailinglist/forums that I can ask this.

I am doing supervised classification on a small-ish dataset of about 8000 sentences, using pretrainedvectors and also without. The code are as follows:


```
'model = fasttext.train_supervised(input=fasttext_train,
                                          minn=4, maxn=10, wordNgrams=3,
                                          neg=10, loss='ns', epoch=3000,
                                          thread=30,
                                          dim=300,
                                          pretrainedVectors=embedding_file)'
#embedding_file points to a pretrained .vec file that is 5GB in size

model = fasttext.train_supervised(input=fasttext_train,
                                              minn=4, maxn=10, wordNgrams=3,
                                              neg=10, loss='ns', epoch=3000,
                                              thread=30,
                                              dim=300)
```
The first line took almost 3 hours while the second took only 40 minutes. I wonder what makes such a big difference?

Could it be:

1. It takes very long time to load very large .vec files? When I use Gensim to load the same .vec file, it took nearly an hour just to load it before it does anything else. I wonder if the same thing is happening here. 
2. It takes a lot of time to perform vector lookups in the pretrained embedding? 
3. anything else?

Can anybody advise on this, or suggest other ways to 'speed things up'? I understand that fasttext can only use the .vec format of pretrained embeddings...

Many thanks

items.title: Wrong documentation (On the web site) for supervised training
items.body:
Hi,

Documentation link: https://fasttext.cc/docs/en/options.html

The documentation states the default for -minn is [3] and -maxn is [6] for supervised training, however when looking deeper into the code C++ code (and python) you will notice that when using Supervised the minn and maxnn is set to 0 instead of using the default 3-6 (Look at the parseArgs function).

Link to the code https://github.com/facebookresearch/fastText/blob/master/src/args.cc

Same happens for the loss and learning rate, they are defaulting to different values than the one written in the documentation.

However for the python version, the supervised default parameters are stated correctly:

Link to the python documentation: https://github.com/facebookresearch/fastText/tree/master/python

Thanks

items.title: Python: predict raises ValueError when doing multiple text when different number of values are above threshold
items.body:
When we are giving `predict()` a list of texts to predict for, each text might produce a different number of results above the given threshold. This raises a ValueError when predict tries to form an `ndarray` out of all the prediction results.

A minimal example to reproduce the error:

```python
import fasttext

text = [
    "Hello hello hello",
    "Foo bar baz",
    "Given a string, get a list of labels and a list of corresponding probabilities."
]

# wget https://dl.fbaipublicfiles.com/fasttext/supervised-models/dbpedia.ftz
model = fasttext.load_model('dbpedia.ftz')
r = model.predict(text, k=100, threshold=0.2)
```

Result:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./test_fasttext.py", line 16, in <module>
    r = model.predict(text, k=100, threshold=0.2)
  File "/home/msjoberg/sw/opt/miniconda3/envs/fasttext/lib/python3.7/site-packages/fasttext/FastText.py", line 151, in predict
    result_as_pair = np.array(predictions, dtype=dt)
ValueError: setting an array element with a sequence.
```

items.title: Cosine distance is unnormalized in find_nearest_neighbor (Python)
items.body:
Some people have mentioned it before me, but I haven't found a specific issue for this.

Cosine distance is wrongly computed in Python version of getNN:

Should be:

`np.matmul(vectors, query, out=cossims) / np.linalg.norm(vectors, axis=1)`

instead of:

`np.matmul(vectors, query, out=cossims)`

Alternatively, the commentary has to be updated to indicate that input vectors should be normalized.
